Not sure what you mean.
 They have a bad interpretation of marriage?
 If they have a good one, then somehow their feelings about gays come into play - there are attributes of gays that are not worthy of marriage. They don't want the fine institution sullied by that ilk.

 
 They simply view marriage as a union between a man and a woman. To them, it isn't possible to have a "marriage" of two men or two women. Obviously, there are people who just hate gay people, but I think most people who oppose gay marriage support civil unions (at least from the people I have talked to). In this case, they are basically saying they support gay marriage as long as it is called something else, which is really quite silly.

In this case, they are basically saying they support gay marriage as long as it is called something else, which is really quite silly.

 
 I have nothing against blacks, I just don't want them in my neighborhood. Some of my best friends are Jewish, but I wouldn't want my sister to marry one. Etc, etc.
 
 Basically, it boils down to "I know I have no reason to dislike this group, I just don't want to associate with them in any way". This sort of attitutude has been all too common in our history, sad to say. Letting gays get married would be admitting that they're more like "normal" people then many want to admit. They want to maintain the illusion that gays are fundamentally different, and that requires treating them differently.

They simply view marriage as a union between a man and a woman. To them, it isn't possible to have a "marriage" of two men or two women. Obviously, there are people who just hate gay people, but I think most people who oppose gay marriage support civil unions (at least from the people I have talked to). In this case, they are basically saying they support gay marriage as long as it is called something else, which is really quite silly.

 
 It really comes down to a failure to see homosexuality as simply a part of the human condition. If one is perfectly content to create an institution for same sex couples that is identical to marriage except for the name "marriage", that is an implicit declaration of the inferiority of gay people. Marriage has been an extremely malleable institution over its history. (The great majority of any changes have had little to do with the "sanctity" of marriage, but usually some contractual change). The idea that somehow in 2006 we want to be rigid about the definition of marriage, considering that history, is a thinly veiled bigotry against gays. These people you describe may not "hate" gays, or may not even consider themselves bigoted, but they have a adopted a fundamental position that gays are not "worthy" of this lofty institution. 
 
 It is "possible" to make marriage anything we want if we care enough to consider who gets affected by any change we make (or lack of change.)

They simply view marriage as a union between a man and a woman. To them, it isn't possible to have a "marriage" of two men or two women. Obviously, there are people who just hate gay people, but I think most people who oppose gay marriage support civil unions (at least from the people I have talked to).  Hm. To me that sounds frighteningly similar to something that could be heard several decades ago: "Our schools should only teach white children. We don't hate gays or anything, we just oppose having them in schools with our children, it just isn't possible to us to allow them in our school. We aren't really opposed to them going to school, we'll support that as long as they go to their own school for blacks and aren't allowed in our white schools. Allowing them in the white schools is just silly." 
 
 I'm sorry, but just like what was decided back then, seperate but equal is NEVER equal. Basically they are saying that gays are somehow inferior and have to be put in their own instisution lest they sully the institution of marriage (something heteros are doing without anyone else's help).

It really comes down to a failure to see homosexuality as simply a part of the human condition. If one is perfectly content to create an institution for same sex couples that is identical to marriage except for the name "marriage", that is an implicit declaration of the inferiority of gay people.

 
 It seems to me the most that could be said is that it might automatically an implicit declaration of the difference of gay people, but not necessarily inferiority. That's not to say of course, that there aren't people (too many) that DO have that view motivating their view of marriage, but I don't think it's fair to claim that the view of them being inferior is always a given in every situation. One certainly can note gay relationships as different (and they are) without viewing them as inferior. The real difference is that a lot of people simply view marriage as an opposite-sex institution. It's that simple. Not rocket science, and nothing else should be read into that without evidence of prejudice. It's sort of like, if a lot of GenX'ers started lobbying and fighting for social security benefits to be an institution available for all ages rather than just over-62s. People generally view it as an over-62 institution, and it's understood that way; has nothing to do with anyone being "inferior." A lot of people view marriage in a similar way, in terms of being opposite-sex. That doesn't mean (as far as I'm concerned, anyway) that we can't look for ways to also give gay couples the benefits they need as well too. But I don't see why we should use an opposite-sex institution to do so.

But I don't see why we should use an opposite-sex institution to do so.

 
 Ah, but it hasn't always been. In fact, in Pagan times, before Christianity took the ceremony for themselves, men could wed men and women could wed women. After that, it was between men and property (the woman was considered property.) and was used for contracts and alliances between families, etc. Then it was whites could only marry whites and blacks could only marry blacks. It it changed this drastically over the years, there is no reason it should not change back to its original definition.

It seems to me the most that could be said is that it might automatically an implicit declaration of the difference of gay people, but not necessarily inferiority. One certainly can note gay relationships as different (and they are) without viewing them as inferior. 

 
 Different here means that gays should not be permitted to marry the way straight people can. That difference is not a lateral one. It is a difference that puts gays at a distinct disadvantage, hence an inferior position.

 I see debating about anti-gay as "trivial and pointless".
 However, as an adjective to help assess what is being discussed, it is often necessary. It is the difference between talking about "Christians" and "anti-gay Christians", which demonstrates a world of difference...
 
 
 
Funny then, that you don't seem to mind the term very much.

 People who have never met me try to determine my worth just based on one word. Just based on one characteristic.
 When you realize the inane craziness of such an attempt, it loses a lot of its punch.
 I find that use of the word reveals more about the user than it does the target.
 
 
 
Yes, and the "glaring derogatory slur" is exactly what I'm talking about, Foundit. Good grief man, stand up for yourself. And other gays. Because from what I see, you don't seem to mind the insult. But to each his own, I guess. emoticon_confused 

 There are more important battles to fight.
 Squawking each time somebody uses the word "perversion" would get the discussion nowhere, although I sometimes debate what constitutes as "perversion", pointing out how arbitrary the user's definition is...
 
 
 
I didn't make a 'clarification', I asked for one. As long as people are going to use loaded and vague terms like 'anti-gay' I'll request they qualify it and explain exactly what they mean. Get used to it, because I'm not going to let people get away with it.

 "loaded and vague"?
 You're the one not getting away with anything here Jyoshu.
 The word was defined. Precisely.
 HOW is it "vague"???
 
 HOW is the word "loaded"?
 
 Never mind. I don't expect a response to those questions as you are obviously intent about complaining, without being capable of substantiating your complaint...

I didn't make a 'clarification', I asked for one. As long as people are going to use loaded and vague terms like 'anti-gay' I'll request they qualify it and explain exactly what they mean. Get used to it, because I'm not going to let people get away with it.

 
 
 Any statement that is not neutral or accepting of gay, is anti-gay.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Gay dating on Fox's Hannity.com website
